intro: Galium multiflorum f. hirsutum, commonly known as the hairy woodbine, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its trailing or climbing growth habit and produces small, fragrant white or pale yellow flowers. The plant features opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a hairy appearance. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. The fruit is a capsule that releases tiny seeds, aiding in its propagation.
